newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippines lowers 1997 budget surplus estimate.
newsitem.headline: Philippines lowers 1997 budget surplus estimate.

text.p: The Philippines budget surplus for 1997 is estimated at 12.135 billion pesos, down from an earlier projected 14.70 billion pesos, according to the government's Development Budget Coordinating Committee (DBCC).
However, the forecast 1997 budget surplus is higher than the actual surplus in 1996 of about 6.26 billion pesos.
The DBCC is a Cabinet-level body comprising the departments of Budget, Finance, the Central Bank and the National Economic Development Authority.

A Finance Department official said the lower budget surplus was mainly brought about by lower forecast revenues of 482.5 billion from 485.1 billion pesos due to the delayed passage of the bills restructuring corporate and individual income taxes.
Disbursements for 1997 were estimated at the same level of 470.41 bllion pesos.

The 1997 budget surplus assumes a real gross national product growth rate of seven to eight percent, an inflation rate of 6.5 percent, a 91-day T-bill rate of 11.0 to 11.5 percent, an exchange rate from 26.36 to 26.72 pesos to the dollar and a 24 percent increase in merchandise imports to $39.96 billion.
